title: Why don't humans have fur?
excerpt: Most mammals, including our closest living relatives, have fur. So why did we lose ours?

title: Something Strange Happens When You Tear These Creatures Apart
excerpt: Behold choanoflagellates, tiny creatures that can be one body and many bodies all at once.

title: When the Next Animal Plague Hits, Can This Lab Stop It?
excerpt: A new federal facility in Kansas will house the deadliest agricultural pathogens in the world—and researchers working tirelessly to contain them.

title: The Evolution of Throwing
excerpt: Homo sapiens has a throwing arm that sets it apart. Athletes are helping anthropologists understand this prowess.

title: Persuading the Body to Regenerate Its Limbs
excerpt: Deer can regrow their antlers, and humans can replace their liver. What else might be possible?

title: Harriet Cole’s Mysterious Identity Still Stumps Historians
excerpt: Whose body was harvested to create a spectacular anatomical specimen, and did that person know they would be on display more than a century later?

title: Why Extraterrestrial Life May Not Seem Entirely Alien
excerpt: The zoologist Arik Kershenbaum argues that because some evolutionary challenges are truly universal, life throughout the cosmos may share certain features.

title: A family with no fingerprints
excerpt: A family in Bangladesh struggles with an extremely rare genetic condition, "immigration delay disease".

title: Louisiana’s Disappearing Coast | The New Yorker
excerpt: The state loses a football field’s worth of land every hour and a half. Now engineers are in a race to prevent it from sinking into oblivion.

title: The Ugly History of Beautiful Things: Orchids
excerpt: Sometimes a flower is just a flower, and sometimes it's a powerful vehicle for giving free rein to our worst colonialist and misogynist impulses.

title: How Do You Save an Endangered Tree from Extinction When You Can't Save Its
excerpt: “Recalcitrant” seeds hold the secret to saving a critically endangered Indian tree—thanks to a bit of human help

title: In Search of Life’s Smoking Gun
excerpt: A journey to the underwater volcanoes where life may have erupted.

title: The transhumanists who want to live forever
excerpt: For a core of longevity true believers, the time to intervene is now.

title: I Now Suspect the Vagus Nerve Is the Key to Well-being
excerpt: “Stimulating” it leads to calmness, but how and why?

title: Solving Wildlife's Strangest Mysteries
excerpt: When a creature mysteriously turns up dead in Alaska—be it a sea otter, polar bear, or humpback whale—veterinary pathologist Kathy Burek gets the call. Her necropsies reveal cause of death and causes for concern as climate change frees up new pathogens and other dangers in a vast, thawing north.

title: The Golden Bough | The New Yorker
excerpt: Grant Hadwin got a chainsaw and did something terrible.

title: This Is Why It's Nearly Impossible to Study Pain
excerpt: A fundamental understanding of what pain is continues to evade scientists.

title: Why plants don’t die from cancer
excerpt: Humans and other mammals and birds would have been killed many times over by Chernobyl's radiation that plants in the most contaminated areas received. So why is plant life so resilient to radiation and nuclear disaster?

title: Why I Traveled the World Hunting for Mutant Bugs - Issue 73: Play
excerpt: A researcher who works through painting tells her story.

title: World's Oldest Terrarium / Sealed Bottle Ecosystem by David Latimer
excerpt: Checkout one of the oldest terrarium gardens in the world! Read the story of David Latimer's sealed bottle ecosystem from the 1960's.

title: How to identify a body: the Marchioness disaster and my life in forensic pa
excerpt: The long read: In my career, I have investigated many of the UK’s worst disasters. Few cases were as harrowing as the sinking of the Marchioness in 1989, which left scores dead and almost impossible to identify
